interlinear-text.item: Gulomali Gulommamad, 50 y.o. Tashkurgan Recorded in 1957.

phrase.item: There once was a fox
The fox and a bear were brothers.
Once, a bird was flying by in the sky.
The fox says to the bear: "Bear, see how the bird flying in the sky doesn't greet me."
The bear says: "O fox, why should [the bird] greet you?"
Said he: "I was the one who made his wings." The bear said: "O fox, how did you make his wings?"
And if you did make his wings, then as I'm your brother, if you can do this, then make me [wings] too, so that I too can fly in the sky like that!"
Said the fox: "Okay, You go bring me branches from a forest, I will make you wings like that."
"Okay," he said.
He got up and walked away.
He went to the forest, took some branches and said: "Hey fox, I went and brought [you] some branches, now you go and make me [my] wings!"
"All right" he said.
He got up and went with him.
Said he: "O bear, you brought me too few branches. Go and bring me more branches.
The bear got up and left again.
He brought the same amount of branches again.
He called the fox again: "O fox, I brought you the same amount of branches again, now get up and make me some wings!"
The fox got up and went with him. Coming to the place where the branches had been brought, he said: "O bear, you brought this, now go and bring me a big rock, then I will make you [your] wings."
The bear got up and left again.
He brought a big rock and called the fox again: "O fox, you've made me really tired, if you're going to make me wings, [then] make [them], if not, leave me be!
The fox said: "Hey, I will make the wings, you go and bring these branches to the top of the tall mountain!"
The bear got up again, and said: "O fox, you tricked me a lot, you get up and make me my wings!"
The fox said: "Okay, let's go, I will make you your wings."
The bear took the fox and they went off.
He took the bear to the place, and the fox said: "O bear, now lie down here, I will make you your wings." The bear lay down.
The fox went, fetched the branches, affixed them in a bundle on his back.
He brought the rock and tied it to his belly.
He brought five ropes, tied him up tight with them, and said: "All right bear, now move yourself!"
The bear moved himself.
Said the fox: "How is it?"
The bear said: "Fox, I'm getting kind of dizzy." The fox said: "Don't be scared now, rise up just a little and plunge ahead!"
The bear said: "Fox, I'm scared." The fox said: "Don't be scared, close your eyes and fly!"
He said: "If I plunge ahead, I'll fall."
The fox said: "Fear nothing."
And closing his eyes, the bear plunged ahead.
He fell off the mountain top [and] crashed [to the ground below].
The fox descended, sank his claws into the bear's backside [and] started eating him.
The bear says: "You, fox, ought to start with the earlobe, that's the sweetest meat right there."
The fox said: "O bear, I started from this side; as to the earlobes, I'll get to them too."
Having done so, he finished the bear's meat and went into the the bear's skin, and went to sleep.
The skin hardened.
The fox became caught inside, one day he said: "O God, if you deliver me from inside this skin, I will be so grateful!"
One night, rain fell.
The skin got soaked, the fox climbed out of it and ran off.
The fox ran and pretended to be dead in the middle of the road.
And along that road, a merchant was riding by. He looks [and sees]: a fox lies on the road.
The merchant took the fox.
He had a load-pack of dried apricots on one of his donkeys.
So he tied the fox to its top.
And the fox made a hole in the sack and started pouring the apricots out of it.
The rope over the sack slackened, the sack was almost empty.
The merchant did not even notice the fox getting free of the rope. He jumped off the sack and ran off, muttering: "Oh God, I am ever so grateful to you!"
